SBDC provide consulting, training and technical assistance to current and prospective small business owners who cannot afford to hire a private consultant. Help is available in starting, improving or expanding a small business.

SCORE provides consulting and training to current and prospective small business owners. SCORE is made up of current and former entrepreneurs who offer their experience and knowledge to help people start, run and grow small businesses. SCORE also offers a variety of small business seminars.
You can visit the SBA website at SSA.gov (English). Visiting the SBA website will allow you to find a variety of information of interest to small business owners.

The IRS issues Individual Taxpayer Identification Numbers (ITINs) to foreign individuals who are U.S. residents, whether temporary or permanent, who do not qualify for a Social Security Number (SSN) and are not eligible to apply for one. An ITIN loses validity in each case when the taxpayer does not file a federal tax return (or is not listed as a dependent on the tax return of another taxpayer) for three consecutive years. Generally, if you need to obtain an ITIN, you must file Form W-7, Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identification Number, with a completed and signed original tax return, and submit other required documentation and mail all to the address specified in the instructions to Form W-7. Exceptions are listed in the instructions. If you need to include the Social Security Number of another person in your tax return but that person does not have a Social Security Number and is not eligible to apply for one, enter the ITIN of that person. The application is also available in Spanish. The form is available at: IRS.gov/FormW7. An ITIN is for tax purposes only. It does not entitle the holder to Social Security benefits or change labor or immigration status.

If you must have an Employer Identification Number (EIN), you must include it with your Social Security Number on Form 1040, Schedule C, according to the instructions. You can apply for an EIN in several ways: Online at IRS.gov/businesses/small; if your principal place of business is in the U.S. or U.S. territories, you will receive an EIN immediately after processing the information you provide on the application, By phone: 267-941-1099 (a fee applies for calls); only if your principal place of business is outside the U.S. or U.S. territories, or By mail or fax: Form SS-4, Application for Employer Identification Number.

If the organizational-legal form of the company or the structure of the company's ownership has changed, you may need to get a new Employer Identification Number. For more information, see Publication 1635, "Employer Identification Number."

"English": "In the course of running a business, you will need to make payments that you must report in an information return. The list of such payments is given in the section "Information Returns" further in this chapter. You must provide the recipient of such payments (the payee) with a statement showing the total amount paid during the year. In the return and in the statement, you must indicate the identification number of the payee and your own identification number."

If you are making payments to a person who is not your employee and you must report such payments on an information return, you need to obtain the social security number of that person. If you must report payments to a certain organization, such as a corporation or partnership, you need to obtain the Employer Identification Number of such organization. To obtain the social security number or Employer Identification Number of the payee, use Form W-9, Request for Taxpayer Identification Number and Certification. A payee who does not provide his or her identification number may be subject to additional withholding. For information on additional withholding, see the instructions for the Form W-9 filer and the general instructions to certain information returns.

You can file your income tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attaching Schedule C. Enter the net profit or loss shown in Schedule C on Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Use Schedule C to calculate your net profit or loss from business. If you operated more than one business as a sole proprietor, you must attach a separate copy of Schedule C for each business.

It's easier than you think to file your tax return electronically. This feature is available to a wide range of taxpayers - even those filing for the first time, since they turned 16 or older by the end of 2024. If you're filing your tax return electronically using tax preparation software or a tax preparer, you'll need to sign your tax return with a self-selected Personal Identification Number (PIN) for the IRS e-file program. If you're married and filing a joint tax return, you and your spouse will each need to create your own PIN and enter it as your electronic signature. To create a PIN, you must know your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) as shown on your original 2023 tax return (do not use the amount shown on your tax return amendment, Form 1040-X, or after an IRS notice). You also need to enter your date of birth (DOB). Your DOB must be correct and match the information you provided to the Social Security Administration before you e-file your tax return. To do this, you must check your Annual Statement of Social Security Benefits. When using a self-selected PIN, you won't need to sign anything or send anything by mail, including Form(s) W-2. For more information about the self-selected PIN, go to IRS.gov.

You can receive a refund check by mail or get a refund direct deposit to your current or savings account. Using IRS e-file, your refund will be issued twice as fast as filing a paper tax return. In most cases, your refund will be issued no later than 21 days after you file.

As with filing a paper tax return, if you have a tax debt, such as federal taxes, state taxes, student loan debt, or child support, you (or, in the case of a joint return, your spouse) may not receive the full amount of your refund. You will receive a notice if your tax refund claim is applied to your debt. You can file a claim for the innocent spouse using Form 8379, 'Payment to an Innocent Spouse' or Form 8857, 'Request for Relief of Innocent Spouse from Tax, Interest and Penalties', to partially or fully recover the amount of the joint refund that was applied to your spouse's individual debt.

IRS will issue refunds for tax returns filed for the purpose of obtaining a tax credit for earned income or an additional child tax credit, no later than mid-February 2025. This provision applies not only to the portion of the refund related to the aforementioned tax credits, but to the entire amount.

For filing your tax return using IRS e-file, you will need only a computer with Internet access. Using your personal computer, you can file your return using e-file from home at any time of the day. To file successfully, you will need to sign your tax return electronically - your own chosen PIN. In this case, you do not need to submit a form to confirm the signature, or Form W-2.

The 1040 or 1040-SR form for 2024 calendar year must be filed by 15 April 2025. If you file a return for a fiscal year (see explanation in Chapter 2), you must file a tax return by the 15th day of the fourth month after the end of your fiscal year. If you fail to file a tax return on time, penalties and interest may be charged. If you are unable to file a tax return on time, you may file Form 4868 «Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File Individual Income Tax Return» to request an automatic six-month extension of the filing deadline. If you file a return for a calendar year using this form, you may extend the filing deadline to 15 October. When filing this form to extend the filing deadline, the tax payment deadline is not extended.

If in 2024 you had insufficient income tax and self-employment tax withheld from your wages or you paid insufficient estimated tax, you may owe a penalty. IRS will calculate the amount of the penalty and send you a bill. You can also use Form 2210, “Underpayment of Income Tax by Individuals, Estates, and Trusts,” to check whether you owe a penalty and calculate the amount of the penalty. For more information, see Publication 505.

Self-employment tax — is a tax on income from self-employment, which is used to fund Social Security and Medicare. It is similar to the Social Security and Medicare tax that is withheld from the paychecks of most wage earners. If you received income as an employee, you do not need to pay self-employment tax on that income. The Social Security and Medicare taxes are already withheld from such income.

Social security benefits are available to both employees and self-employed individuals. The tax on self-employed individuals is credited when determining the amount of social security benefits. Through the social security system, you receive pension payments, payments for people with disabilities, survivor benefits, and also cover hospital expenses (Medicare). You must report all income from self-employment. Otherwise, when you retire, you will receive fewer social security benefits.

For 2024, you received one credit from the maximum of four credits for every $1,730 of taxable income ($1,810 in 2025). Thus, if you earned $6,920 in 2024, you would receive four credits (6,920 ÷ 1,730). You can find out how many credits you need to qualify for Social Security and Medicare benefits for yourself and your family by contacting your local Social Security office. You may be fined for filing false statements to get or increase Social Security benefits.

As a rule, the Social Security Administration will only credit a self-employment income report if it is presented in a tax return filed within 3 years, 3 months and 15 days after the tax year in which the income was earned. If you file a tax return or report a change in self-employment income after this time, the Social Security Administration will only accept a request to cancel or reduce the income. The Social Security Administration will not change your self-employment income upwards.

In 2024, only the first $168,600 of total earnings, which includes wages, tips, and net profit, is subject to any combination of the self-employment tax in the Social Security portion of the self-employment tax rate of 12.4%, the Social Security tax, or the Medicare tax in the Railroad Retirement Board pension fund. In 2024, the full amount of your wages, tips, and net profit is subject to any combination of the self-employment tax in the Medicare portion of the self-employment tax rate of 2.9%, the Medicare tax, or the Medicare tax in the Railroad Retirement Board pension fund. If your wages and tips as a non-employee are subject to the Social Security tax, the Medicare tax, or both, and your income is at least $168,600, you do not need to pay the Social Security tax in the self-employment tax rate of 12.4% on any net profit. However, you must pay the Medicare tax in the self-employment tax rate of 2.9% on the full net profit. You can deduct half of the self-employment tax as a deduction in Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

If you receive income from both employment and self-employment, the limit applied to the Medicare tax on self-employment income is reduced (but not below zero) by the amount of employment income subject to the Medicare tax. Use Form 8959, 'Medicare Tax' to figure the amount of this tax.

For more information, see Publication 15 (Circular E), Employer’s Tax Guide. In this publication, your tax obligations as an employer are listed. Do not reduce the amount of deductions for taxes paid to Social Security and Medicare funds by the amount of non-refundable and refundable portions of sick leave and family leave credits received under the FFCRA (The Families First Coronavirus Relief Act) and the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, and indicated on your employer’s tax return. Instead, report these credits as income. To determine whether individuals working for your company are your employees, see Publication 15-A. In this publication, you will find information that will help you determine whether a person is an independent contractor or an employee. If you mistakenly report a person as an independent contractor when they are an employee, you may be liable for payroll taxes for that person plus a penalty.

The federal excise tax, which must be reported in Form 720, the Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, includes several categories of taxes, including the following. Environmental protection tax on the sale or use of substances that destroy the ozone layer and imported products containing or produced with such substances. Communications and air transportation taxes. Fuel tax. Tax on the first retail sale of large trucks, trailers, and tractors. Manufacturer's tax on the sale or use of a number of different goods. Tanning services tax.

"English": "The use of certain types of heavy-duty trucks, tractor-trailers, and buses operating on public roads is subject to a federal excise tax. This tax applies to vehicles whose gross tax-paid weight is 55,000 pounds (25,000 kg) or more. You must file Form 2290, "Road Use Tax Return," to report this tax. For more information, see the instructions for Form 2290."

If you are engaged in business activity and you make or receive payments, you may need to file a report of them with the IRS on an information return. To verify that payments are included in income, the IRS compares the payments listed on the information return with the income tax return of each individual. You must file a copy of each information return that you are required to file with the payee or payor. In addition to the forms listed below for reporting certain types of payments or monetary transactions, you may need to file other types of returns. For more information about information returns and filing deadlines, see the general instructions to some information returns.

Regardless of the amount of the payment, you must also file Form 1099-NEC for each person from whom you withheld any federal income tax (see box 4), according to the additional rules for withholding. If you file Form 1099-NEC for reporting sales of consumer goods of $5,000 or more, you must file this form with IRS by January 31.

According to the law, penalties are imposed for the failure to file the following forms: Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC or Form W-2. Penalties are also imposed for the provision of incorrect information. For more information, see the general instructions to some information returns. Failure to file an information return. In cases of failure to file an information return by the due date, failure to include all necessary information or reporting incorrect information, a penalty is imposed. Failure to provide correct reports to the payee. In cases of failure to provide the required report to the payee by the due date, failure to include all necessary information or reporting incorrect information, a penalty is imposed.

If you can prove that the violation was committed for reasonable reasons, rather than by willful neglect, you will be exempt from penalties. In addition, no penalty will be imposed for failing to include all necessary information or for stating incorrect information in de minimis (insignificant) number of information returns when correcting errors before August 1 of the year in which the return is required to be filed. (De minimis - 10 returns or half of 1% of the total number of returns (whichever is greater) that you are required to file for the year.)

You must file Form 8300, Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000, if you receive more than $10,000 in cash from a trade or business in one or more cash transactions. The report covers cash payments in U.S. and foreign currency. Certain money market instruments, such as cashier's checks, travelers checks, and money orders are also reportable. Personal checks are not reportable. For more information, see Publication 1544, Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000.

You must calculate your taxable income and file a tax return for the annual reporting period called the tax year. In addition, you must always use a method of accounting that clearly shows your income and expenses for the tax year.

Вы должны использовать один и тот же метод учета для расчета налогооблагаемого дохода и ведения бухгалтерских документов. Кроме того, вы должны использовать метод учета, который четко показывает ваш доход.

Вы можете вести учет коммерческих и личных статей доходов и расходов с помощью различных методов учета. Например, вы можете рассчитать свой коммерческий доход методом начисления, даже если вы используете кассовый метод для расчета личных статей доходов и расходов.

Если у вас есть два или более отдельных и разных направления коммерческой деятельности, вы можете использовать разные методы учета для каждого, если этот метод четко отражает доход каждого направления. Они являются отдельными и разными только в том случае, если вы ведете полные и разные документы и записи для каждого направления.

Under the cash method, include in your gross income all items of income that you actually or constructively receive during the tax year. If you receive property or services, you must include their fair market value in income.

You have implied income when the amount is credited to your account or given to you without restrictions. You do not have to own it. If you have appointed someone as your agent, it is considered that you have received income when your agent has received it.

You cannot hold checks or defer taking possession of similar property from one tax year to another to avoid paying income tax. You must report income for the year in which the property was received by you or given to you without restrictions.

If your debts are paid by someone else or canceled by your creditors, you may have to report all or part of the canceled debt as income. If you receive income in this way, you have income from cancellation of debt. For more information, see the section “Canceled Debt” in the “Types of Income” chapter in Chapter 5.

{ "English": "If you include a specific amount in income and in the following year you need to fully or partially reimburse it, you can generally deduct the reimbursement amount in the year in which you made it. If the amount you reimbursed exceeds $3,000, a special rule applies. For details about the special rule, see "Reimbursement Payments" in Chapter 8 of Publication 17." }

The cash method is the most common method of accounting for expenses. Under this method, you deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them. This method is generally used for small businesses and individuals. Under the cash method, you do not deduct expenses that you have not actually paid. For example, if you have a business expense that you have not yet paid, you do not deduct it in the tax year in which you incurred the expense. You must deduct the expense in the tax year in which you actually pay it.
You can only deduct pre-paid expenses in the year to which they relate.

In accordance with the accrual method, you generally report income in the year it is earned and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year they are incurred. The purpose of accrual accounting is to match income and expenses for the appropriate year.

When using the accrual method, you generally include the amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all events that establish your right to the income occurred, and you can determine this amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer with a proper financial statement or other financial statement prepared in accordance with the regulations of the ministry of finance, the 'all events' test for an item of gross income is considered satisfied no later than when it is recorded in the proper financial statement or other similar financial statement.

If you include a reasonably estimated amount in gross income and later determine that the exact amount is different, take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determine that amount.

If you are providing services at the base rate specified in the contract, you must record income at the base rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate until you complete the services, and then receive the difference.

As a rule, you report the advance payment as income in the year you receive it. However, if you receive an advance payment, you can defer including the advance payment in income until the following tax year. You cannot defer including any payment to the following tax year. For more information, see Publication 538 and section 451.

According to the accrual method, you generally deduct or capitalize business expenses if both of the following conditions are met. 1. The event-based requirement is satisfied. This requirement is considered satisfied when: 1. All events that fix the fact of liability have occurred, 2. and liability can be determined with reasonable certainty. 2. Economic substance has been achieved.

"English": "As a rule, you cannot deduct or capitalize business expenses until economic benefit is realized. If your expenses are related to property or services provided to you or to the use of property by you, economic benefit is realized as the property or services are provided or as the property is used. If your expenses are related to property or services that you provide to others, economic benefit is realized as you provide the property or services. An exception allows you to treat certain recurring items as incurred during the tax year even if economic benefit has not been realized. See the "Economic Benefit" section of Publication 538, "Method of Accounting," for more information about economic benefit."

When production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in generating income in your business activity, you generally must keep inventory records at the beginning and end of the tax year if you are not a small business taxpayer. When keeping inventory records, you must use the accrual method for recording purchases and sales. For more information, see Inventory, later.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest due to a related person who uses the cash method of accounting until you make the payment and the amount is included in the gross income of the related person. Determine the degree of relationship for this rule at the end of the tax year in which the expenses or interest would otherwise be deductible. If the deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with this person ends before the expenses or interest are included in the gross income of the person. Related persons include your family members, including brothers and sisters (whole or half), your spouse, ancestors and descendants in a direct line. See section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code for a list of other related persons.

If you are a small business owner, you can choose not to include inventory in your assets, but you still must use a method of accounting for inventory that clearly reflects your income. If you decide not to include inventory in your assets, this will not be a sign of inability to clearly reflect income if your method of accounting for inventory considers MTO (material handling equipment) as planned materials or inventory or if it matches your financial inventory accounting method. However, if you decide to include inventory in your assets, you generally must use a accrual method and value inventory each year to determine the cost of goods sold in Part III of Schedule C.

You are considered a small business owner if you (a) have average annual gross income of $30 million or less for the 3 previous tax years and (b) are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448(d)(3)). If your business did not exist for the entire 3-year tax period used to calculate average gross income, calculate the average for the period it existed, and if your business has a predecessor, include the gross income of the predecessor for the 3-year tax period when calculating average gross income. If your business (or predecessor) had short tax years for any of the 3 tax years, recalculate the gross income of your business for the short tax years that are part of the 3-year tax period. For more information, see Publication 538.

You must value your Inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine the cost of goods sold (App. C, line 42). To determine the cost of your Inventory, you need a method of identifying the income and expense items in your Inventory and a method of valuing these items. The rules for valuing Inventory cannot be the same for all types of business. The method you use to value your Inventory must be in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles for similar types of business and clearly reflect the income. Your inventory valuation methods must be used consistently from year to year.

You may be subject to the single business entity rules if you are engaged in one of the following activities, except where the property is intended for personal use, rather than business or activity undertaken for profit. Manufacturing immovable or tangible personal property. In this context, tangible personal property includes film, recording, videotape, book or similar property. Acquiring property for resale.

There are special methods of accounting for certain items of income or expenses. These include the following methods. Depreciation of intangible assets, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225. Bad debts, discussed in Topic No. 453 «Write-off of a Bad Debt». Depletion, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225. Depreciation, discussed in Publication No. 946 «How to Depreciate Property». Sale on credit, discussed in Publication No. 537 «Sale on credit». Long-term contractual methods of accounting. See Section 460.

An equal-value exchange is the exchange of property for other property of equal value. This is the most common type of non-taxable transaction. To be equal-value, the exchanged and received property must be (a) real property and (b) property of a business or investment. An equal-value exchange should be reported on Form 8824, Equalized Exchange. For more information about equal-value exchanges, see Chapter 1 of Publication 544.

A sale on credit is a sale of property where you receive at least one payment after the tax year of the sale. If you extend credit to a buyer of your property instead of the buyer obtaining credit or a mortgage from a third party, you sell property on credit. For more information about sales on credit, see Publication 537.

"English": "The sale of a business is usually not the sale of a single asset. Instead, all of the assets of the business are sold. Typically, in this case, each asset is treated as separately sold. The buyer and seller participating in the sale of a business must report to the IRS the allocation of the sale price among the assets of the business. You are a real estate agent if you are engaged in selling real estate to clients for the purpose of deriving profit from these sales. Rental income from a trailer park is subject to SE tax if you are a self-employed owner of a trailer park, renting out rooms and parking spaces, and providing substantial services to tenants for their convenience. Generally, you provide substantial services to tenants if they are primarily for the tenants' convenience and are not typically provided to maintain the lots in a habitable condition. Services are considered substantial if the compensation for them is a substantial part of the tenants' rent payments. Examples of services that are typically not provided for the tenants' convenience include the operation and maintenance of a recreation hall provided by the park, the mailing of a monthly newsletter to tenants, the operation of a laundry and assistance to tenants in buying or selling their trailers. Examples of services that are typically provided to maintain the lots in a habitable condition for tenants include city sewer, electricity, and roads.

Income from rental, received by you for using or occupying hotels, guest houses or multi-apartment houses, is subject to SE tax if you provide services to tenants. Generally, it is considered that you provide services to tenants if these services are primarily for their convenience and are not services normally provided when renting rooms only for living. An example of services that are not normally provided for the convenience of tenants is maid service. However, providing heat and light, cleaning stairways and hallways, and removing garbage are services normally provided for the convenience of tenants.
The bonus you receive from the tenant for renting out the property is an addition to the rent. Include it in gross income in the year you receive it.

If your tenant makes payments to someone else under an agreement to pay your debts or obligations, include these payments in gross income when the tenant makes the payments. A common example of this type of income is the tenant's payment of your property taxes on the leased real estate.

Rental payments are any amounts you pay for the use of property that does not belong to you. Generally, you can deduct rental payments as business expenses only if the rental payments are for property that you use in your business. You cannot claim a deduction for rent paid for an uncommercial rental. Generally, a question of uncommerciality arises only if you and the tenant are related. Rent paid to a relative is commercial if it is equal to the amount you would pay to a stranger for the use of the same property. Rent is not uncommercial simply because it is calculated as a percentage of gross income. Relatives include members of your nearest family, including siblings (full or half), your spouse, ancestors and descendants in the direct line. If someone owes you money that you can't get, you have an uncollectible debt. There are two types of uncollectible debts — business and nonbusiness. Business uncollectible debts usually arise from professional or business activities. You can deduct uncollectible debts as expenses on your tax return.

Debts are considered closely related to your business activity if the main motive for their occurrence was business activity. Uncollectible debts in business activity are mainly the result of selling goods and services to customers on credit. They may also be the result of loans to suppliers, customers, employees or distributors. Goods and services for which customers have not paid are recorded in your books as accounts receivable or notes receivable. If you cannot collect any part of this receivable, then the uncollectible part is an uncollectible debt. You can take a deduction for uncollectible debts on these accounts and notes receivable only if the amount of the debt was included in your gross income, either for the year in which the deduction is claimed or for the preceding year.

If you claimed a bad debt deduction on your tax return and later collect (recover) all or part of that debt, you may have to include all or part of the amount collected in your gross income. You must include in your income the amount you actually claimed as a deduction. However, you can exclude from income the amount of the deduction that did not reduce your tax. Report the amount collected as «Other income» on the appropriate tax form or schedule. For more information, see Publication 525, «Tax Guide to U.S. Citizens and Residents Living Abroad».

If a bad debt deduction increases your carryover NOL, which has not expired before the beginning of the tax year in which the debt is collected, this deduction is classified as a reduction of your tax. Bad debt deductions that affect your NOL reduce your tax in the year you carry forward NOL. For more information about NOL for individuals, see Publication 536. Also see the instructions for Form 1045 and the instructions for Form 1139.

If you use accrual accounting, you typically report income when you earn it. You can take a bad debt deduction for uncollectible accounts receivable if you included the uncollectible amount in income.

First, you should familiarize yourself with the provisions of the tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular convention, if any, to determine whether your salary is exempt from US income tax under these provisions. Generally, you are not eligible for the tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or a bilateral consular convention if you are a US citizen or a US resident alien. For further information regarding the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular conventions, contact the Office of Foreign Missions of the Department of State at OFMAssistants@state.gov (English).

If you are not exempt from taxation under the Vienna Conventions or bilateral consular treaties, but are a citizen of a country that has a tax treaty with the United States, you should consult that treaty to determine if there is a provision that exempts your salary from United States income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or a foreign resident working in the United States for a foreign government, your salary is generally not exempt from tax. For more information, see Section 901 of Publication 901, Foreign Income and FELIN Tax Treatment of Foreign Income and Foreign-Source Income of U.S. Citizens and Residents.

Foreign government employees who do not fall under the provisions of the tax exemption of any of the Vienna Conventions, a bilateral consular convention, or a tax treaty, may be exempt from US income tax if they meet the following requirements for exemption from US tax on such compensation under US tax law. The exemption from US tax under US tax law applies only to current employees of foreign governments, but not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of foreign governments residing in the US are not covered by the exemption discussed here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. To determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor, the common law rules apply. See Publication 1779 (English) and Publication 15-A (English). Your compensation is not exempt from US tax under US tax law if you work for a “controlled commercial organization” or your services are primarily related to commercial activities of a foreign government (within or outside the US). A controlled commercial organization is an organization that is 50% (0.50) or more owned by a foreign government and engaged in commercial activity in the US or outside the US.

Many agreements establishing international organizations contain a provision that may exempt your salary from US income tax. If you work for an international organization in the United States, first check whether the international agreement establishing the international organization you work for contains such a provision, and whether you qualify for it. Generally, these provisions do not exempt from income tax the salaries of US citizens and residents-foreigners.

If you are a US citizen, you are not eligible for the exemption discussed here. However, you may be eligible for a foreign tax credit for taxes paid to a foreign country. See Publication 519 (English) for more information.

If you sign a waiver provided for in Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (Form USCIS I-508) to maintain your status as a legal permanent resident (green card), you are no longer eligible for tax exemption under US tax law from the date of filing the waiver. If you are an employee of a foreign government or an international organization and hold a green card, to qualify for tax exemption under US tax law, you must also provide a written statement from USCIS that you did not sign or file Form USCIS I-508.

If you are a non-citizen, you must qualify under category (1) or (2) above, and you have filed a request for waiver under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain an exit permit. This rule applies even if your income is exempt from US taxes because of a tax treaty, a consular agreement, or an international agreement.

To obtain a tax clearance, you must visit a TAC office (see above) at least 2 weeks before you leave the United States and file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C, as well as any other necessary tax returns that have not been filed. The clearance cannot be issued more than 30 days before your departure. If you and your spouse are both foreigners and both leaving the United States, you both must visit a TAC office. Note that all TAC offices are by appointment only. You can call 844-545-5640 from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. local time to schedule an appointment. For more information about your local TAC office, go to IRS.gov/TAC ..

Obtaining permission to leave will be faster if you bring to the TAC office documents relating to your income and your stay in the United States. Bring with you the following documents if they apply to you. 1. Your passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your United States income tax returns filed for the past 2 years. If you have been in the United States for less than 2 years, bring tax returns filed for that period. 3. Receipts for income tax payments on these returns. 4. Bank statements, canceled checks, and other documents showing your deductions, business expenses, and dependents listed on your income. 5. A statement from each employer showing your earnings and taxes withheld from 1 January of the current year to the date of departure, if you were an employee. If you were self-employed, you must provide a statement of income and expenses to the date you plan to leave. 6. A statement showing your expected tax payments for the past and current year. 7. Documents showing any income or loss from the sale of personal and/or real property, including capital assets and merchandise. 8. Documents relating to scholarships or grants, including... 1. documentary evidence of the source, purpose, and amount of the grant. 2. copies of the grant application and its approval. 3. a statement of the amount paid, as well as your tasks and obligations under the grant. 4. a list of all previous grants. 9. Documents showing your right to claim the special tax benefits claimed. 10. A document showing your date of departure from the United States, such as an airline ticket. 11. A document showing your United States individual tax payer identification number (TIN), such as a social security card or a CP 565 notice from the IRS, showing your individual tax payer identification number (ITIN).

Foreigners in any of these categories who did not file a return or pay income tax for any tax year must file a tax return and pay income tax before they are issued a Form 2063 exit permit. A Form 2063 exit permit can be used for any departure during the current year. However, IRS may revoke the exit permit for any later departure if the agency determines that such later departure may interfere with the collection of income tax.

If you are a nonresident alien and you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien, you must file Form 1040-C to obtain an exit permit. If you are a nonresident alien and you are not a U.S. citizen or resident alien, you must file Form 1040-C if you are a nonresident alien for the tax year in which you are leaving the United States. If you are a nonresident alien for the tax year in which you are leaving the United States, but you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien for the tax year immediately preceding the tax year in which you are leaving the United States, you must file Form 1040-C to obtain an exit permit.

If you provide the IRS information showing to the satisfaction of the agency that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax, you may obtain permission to depart by filing Form 1040-C without paying the tax shown thereon. However, you must file all tax returns that have not been properly filed and pay all income tax due on those returns. Your Form 1040-C must include all income received and reasonably expected to be received during the year of departure. The permission to depart issued together with this Form 1040-C may be used for all departures during the current year. However, the IRS may revoke the permission to depart for any later departure if it would prevent the collection of income tax.

You must pay all taxes shown as payable on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, except where a bond is furnished, or the IRS is confident that your departure will not interfere with the collection of income tax. You also must pay any tax liabilities for prior years. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, no tax is collected when you file the return. However, the IRS cannot issue a refund at the time of departure. If you are entitled to a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

Form 1040-C is not an annual income tax return for the United States. If a tax return is required by law, this return must be filed even if a Form 1040-C has already been filed. Chapter 5 and Chapter 7 discuss the procedure for filing an annual income tax return for the United States. The tax paid using Form 1040-C must be credited against tax liabilities for the entire tax year in your annual income tax return for the United States.

Do not count the days you travel to the United States from your residence in Canada or Mexico if you regularly travel to work from Canada or Mexico. You are considered to regularly travel to work if you travel to work in the United States more than 75% (0.75) of your working days during your working period. For this purpose, ‘travel to work’ means travel to work and return to your residence within 24 hours. ‘Working days’ are the days you work in the United States, Canada or Mexico. ‘Working period’ means the period beginning with the first day of the current year that you physically are in the United States for work and ending with the last day of the current year that you physically are in the United States for work. If your work requires your presence in the United States only on a seasonal or cyclical basis, your working period begins on the first day of the season or cycle during which you are in the United States for work and ends on the last day of the season or cycle during which you are in the United States for work. You may have more than one working period in a calendar year, and your working period may begin in one calendar year and end in the next calendar year.

Tax home is the total area of your principal place of business, employment or service, regardless of where you reside. Tax home is the place where you are employed as an employee or self-employed for a substantial period of time. If you do not have a permanent or principal place of employment due to the nature of your business, your tax home is the place where you regularly reside. If you do not fit into either of these categories, you are considered a person who moves from place to place, and your tax home is the place where you work. To determine whether you have a closer connection to another country, your tax home must also exist for the entire current year and be in the same foreign country as the one with which, according to your claims, you have a closer connection.

When determining whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country, the term 'foreign country' is... any territory under the sovereignty of the United Nations or a government other than the United States, the territorial waters of a foreign state (as defined by U.S. law), the seabed and subsoil of those underwater areas adjacent to the territorial waters of a foreign state, and over which the foreign state has exclusive rights under international law to explore and develop natural resources, and territories administered by the United States.

Double residents. The rules described here for determining whether you are a resident of the United States do not supersede the definitions of residency in tax treaties. If you are a double-resident taxpayer, you may still qualify for treaty benefits. A double-resident taxpayer is a taxpayer who is a resident of the United States and another country under the tax laws of each of those countries. A tax treaty between two countries should contain a provision that resolves conflicting claims of residency (the “tie-breaker” rule). If you are considered a resident of a foreign country under the tax treaty, you are considered a nonresident alien for United States income tax purposes. For other purposes, other than income tax, you will be considered a resident of the United States. For example, the rules described here do not affect the time you spend in a country, as described in the section “Double-Status Aliens” below.

You can be both a nonresident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year. This usually happens in the year you arrive in the United States or leave the United States. Aliens with dual status should refer to Chapter 6 for information on filing a return for a tax year with dual status.

If you were a U.S. resident for any part of the previous calendar year and are a U.S. resident for any part of the current year, you will be considered a U.S. resident at the beginning of the current year. Foreign resident income is generally taxed in the same way as income of US citizens. If you are a foreign resident, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other services, rental income or royalties, and other types of income on your US tax return. You must report these amounts from sources in the US and from sources outside the US.

Foreign non-resident individuals are taxed only on their income from sources in the United States and on a limited amount of income related to the conduct of a trade or business in the United States (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from sources in the United States, applicable to most foreign non-residents, are shown in Table 2-1. The following discussions cover the general rules, as well as exceptions to those rules. Not all articles of income from sources in the United States are taxed. See Chapter 3 ..

Real property is land and buildings, and generally all that is built on, or attached to, the land. Gross income from sources within the United States includes gains, profits, and income from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the United States.

Revenue from the sale of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural resource, or timber, located in the United States and sold in a foreign country, or located in a foreign country and sold in the United States, is partly income from sources in the United States. See regulations, section 1.863-1(b) for more details on this part.

Personal property is property such as cars, equipment, or furniture that is not real property. Profits or losses from the sale or exchange of personal property are generally sourced to the U.S. if your tax home is in the U.S. If your tax home is not in the U.S., then profits or losses are generally treated as sourced outside the U.S.

Inventory is personal property used in trade or held for sale in the ordinary course of business. Income from the sale of inventory you own is generally considered income from a U.S. source, even if you acquired the inventory in a foreign country. Income from the sale of inventory you produced in the U.S. and sold outside the U.S. (or vice versa) is generally considered income from the place where the property was produced. These rules apply even if your U.S. tax home is not in the U.S.

To determine the source of income from the sale of depreciable personal property, you must first calculate the portion of the income that does not exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments for the property. You apportion this portion of the profit among sources in the United States on the basis of the ratio of depreciation adjustments in the United States to the total amount of depreciation adjustments. The remaining portion of the profit is considered income from sources outside the United States. In this case, «depreciation adjustments in the United States» is depreciation adjustments to the base of the property that are permitted in calculating taxable income from sources in the United States. However, if the property is used predominantly in the United States during the tax year, all depreciation deductions permitted for that year are treated as depreciation adjustments in the United States. There are, however, some exceptions for certain vehicles, communications equipment, and other property used internationally. Profits from the sale of depreciable property that exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments for the property are treated as if the property were merchandise inventory, as discussed above. Losses are treated in the same way as depreciation deductions. However, if the property was used predominantly in the United States, the entire loss reduces income from a United States source. The base of the property generally means the cost (money plus fair market value of other property or services) of the property you acquired. Depreciation is the amount you deduct to recover the cost or other base of an asset used in a trade or business. The amount you can deduct depends on the cost of the property, when you began using the property, how long it will take to recover the cost, and the depreciation method you use. A depreciation deduction is any deduction for wear and tear, depreciation, or any other allowable deduction that makes capital expenditures deductible expenses.

"English": "Non-tangible property includes patents, copyrights, trade secrets or formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names and other similar property. Profits from the sale of amortizable or amortizable non-tangible property within previously allowed depreciation or depreciation deductions are treated in the same manner as the original deductions. This rule is similar to the source rule for profits from the sale of depreciable property. See the "Amortizable Property" section above for detailed information on how to apply this rule. Profits in excess of depreciation deductions are treated as source in the country where the property is used, if the income from the sale is dependent on the productivity, use or disposition of the property. If the income is not dependent on the productivity, use or disposition of the property, then the income is determined in accordance with your tax home (discussed above). If payments for goodwill are not dependent on its productivity, use or disposition, the source of the income is the country in which the goodwill was created."

Regardless of any of the above rules, if your tax home is not in the United States, but you have an office or other permanent place of business in the United States, income from any sale of personal property (including inventory) relating to that office or place of business is considered income from a U.S. source. However, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory for use, disposition, or consumption outside the United States, if your office or other permanent place of business outside the United States took substantial part in the sale. If you have a tax home in the United States, but you have an office or other permanent place of business outside the United States, income from the sale of personal property other than inventory, depreciable property, or intangible assets relating to that foreign office or place of business may be considered income from a U.S. source. Income is considered income from a U.S. source if income tax of less than 10% of the income from the sale is paid to a foreign country. This rule also applies to losses, if a foreign country would have imposed income tax of less than 10%, if the sale had resulted in a profit.

Income from U.S. sources does not include the following items. 1. Interest on deposits in a foreign branch of a domestic corporation or partnership, but only if the branch is engaged in commercial banking.

In most cases, income in the form of dividends received from domestic corporations is US source income. Dividend income from foreign corporations is generally foreign source income. An exception to the second rule is discussed later. A substitute payment of dividends to a person who transfers securities in a loan of securities transaction or a sale with a repurchase agreement is treated in the same manner as a distribution on the transferred securities.

Payment of an amount equivalent to dividends includes any gross amount that refers to dividends from a U.S. source and that is used to calculate any net amount paid to or by a taxpayer under a contract, if the taxpayer is a party under a contract entitled to receive payments. As a result, a taxpayer may be treated as having received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or does not pay any amount because the net amount is zero. In 2024, NPC or ELI, as the case may be, will generally be the designated NPC or designated ELI, respectively, if the contract relates to derivative financial instrument transactions of the delta-one type. Generally, delta is the ratio of the change in the fair market value of NPC or ELI to a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares specified in the contract. Generally, the dividend equivalent amount for a particular NPC or ELI is the dividend per share multiplied by the number of shares specified in the contract multiplied by the contract delta. More complex contracts are subject to special rules. For further information, see Section 1.871-15 of the regulations and Notice 2024-44 (or subsequent notices).

The above-mentioned additional benefits, excluding tax reimbursement and payments for work in dangerous or heavy conditions, are calculated at the main place of work. The main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. This may be your office, factory, store, store or other place. If there is no such place where you spend most of your working time, then your main place of work is the place where your work is concentrated, for example, where you go to work or where you are required to «do» your work. If you have several places of work at the same time, the place of your main place of work depends on the facts in each particular case. The most important factors to consider are... the total time you spend in each place, the amount of work you do in each place, and how much money you earn in each place.

If you are an employee, you can determine the source of your compensation on an alternative basis if you can show the IRS that, based on the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative basis more correctly determines the source of your compensation than the temporary or geographic basis. A comparison of the dollar amount of U.S. compensation and foreign compensation received as on the alternative basis and on the temporary or geographic basis discussed above.

Transportation income is income from the use of a watercraft or aircraft or for performing services directly related to the use of any watercraft or aircraft. This is true whether the watercraft or aircraft is owned, leased, or rented. The term 'watercraft or aircraft' includes any container used in connection with a watercraft or aircraft. All transportation income that begins and ends in the United States is considered income from sources in the United States. If transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the transportation income is considered income from sources in the United States. Transportation income that is part of personal services, 50% of the transportation income is income from sources in the United States, if transportation is between the United States and one of the territories under the jurisdiction of the United States. For nonresident aliens, this applies only to income from an aircraft or in connection with an aircraft. See chapter 4 for more information on how transportation income from a source in the United States is taxed.

Your income from a US source is taxable income that is included in your total US government base pay, excluding nontaxable pay for services performed outside the United States.

The 30% (or lower, as per the agreement) rate applies to the gross amount of fixed, determined, annual or periodic (FDAP) income, revenue or profit from a US source. Income is considered fixed when it is paid in known, predetermined amounts. Income is determined whenever there is a basis for determining the amount to be paid. Income may be periodic if it is paid from time to time. It need not be paid annually or at regular intervals. Income may be fixed or periodic, even if the time period for payments increases or decreases. Articles specifically included as fixed or determined income are interest (except for original issue discount (OID)), dividends, payments, equivalent to dividends (as defined in Chapter 2), rent, premiums, annuities, wages and other compensation. Substitution dividends or interest payments received in connection with a securities lending or securities sale transaction are treated as amounts received on the security. Other income items, such as royalties, may also be taxed at 30%. Some fixed or determined income may be exempt from US taxation. If you are unsure whether income is taxable, see Chapter 3 ..

Under a certain number of tax treaties, you may be able to deduct contributions to a foreign charitable organization. For more information, see Publication 526 (English).

You can deduct losses from accidents and thefts on your tax return. You can deduct an accident that is not related to business or a theft, only if it is caused by a federal disaster. If an accident or theft occurred to you as a result of a federal disaster, you can deduct the loss even if your property is not related to business or commercial activity in the United States. Property can be personal or income-producing property not related to business or commercial activity in the United States. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the accident or theft. You can deduct a theft loss only in the year you discover the theft. Use Form 4684 and its instructions to figure the losses from theft and accidents. For more information, see Publication 547.

Any federal income tax withheld from your wages during the tax year in which you were a nonresident alien is allowed as a payment toward your U.S. income tax liability for that year. You may elect to have the tax withheld during the year applied to your U.S. tax liability for that year regardless of whether you were engaged in a trade or business in the United States during the year and whether the wages (or any other income) were related to a trade or business in the United States.

Your employer is responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) additional tax in the Medicare fund from your salary or pension payments for railway workers (RRTA) exceeding $200,000 in 2024. If you do not have a balance in the additional tax in the Medicare fund, you can claim a credit for any withheld additional tax in the Medicare fund against your total tax liability shown on your tax return by completing Form 8959.

You may use as payment any tax withheld from your investment income or from any other fixed or determinable annual or periodic income you receive. Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rent and royalties that you do not call actually connected income. Wages or salary may be fixed or determinable income to you and are usually subject to withholding, as described above. Taxes on fixed or determinable income are withheld at a 30% rate or at a lower contractual rate.

"English": "If you are a nonresident alien who is a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed as a nonresident alien. You must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and report information about all income from sources within and outside the United States. However, you may exclude income described in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than reporting income, you will be treated as a nonresident alien. For example, you are not allowed the standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot claim a dependent if that person is not a U.S. citizen or resident of a U.S. territory. There are also limitations on which deductions and credits are allowed. See the "Nonresident Aliens" section in the "Deductions" and "Itemized Deductions" sections, and also the "Tax Credits and Payments" section in this chapter."

You must calculate your income and file a tax return based on the annual accounting period called the tax year. If you have not previously established a financial tax year, your tax year will be the calendar year. The calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a standard financial year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a 52 or 53 week year) and consider yourself a resident of the United States during any calendar year, you will be considered a resident of the United States during any part of the financial year that falls within that calendar year.

The Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) must be included in tax returns, forms, and other tax documents. For a natural person, this is the Social Security Number (SSN). If you do not have an SSN and are not eligible to obtain one, you must file an application for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN). An Employer Identification Number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in business or self-employment activity and have employees or a qualified retirement plan. You must provide a Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) if you... are a non-resident alien whose income is directly related to business or self-employment activity in the United States at any time during the year; are a non-resident alien with an office or place of business in the United States at any time during the year; are a spouse-nonresident alien considered a resident for purposes of chapter 1; or are any other non-resident alien who files a tax return, an amended tax return, or a claim for refund (but not an informational return).

As a rule, you can get a SSN if you were legally admitted to the United States for permanent residence or in other immigration categories that allow employment in the United States. If you do not have a Social Security Number, contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) to determine if you are eligible. For more information, visit SSA.gov (English) or call 800-772-1213 (for deaf or hard-of-hearing, call TTY 800-325-0778).

If you have an F-1, M-1, or J-1 visa, see Pub. SSA 05-10181, available at SSA.gov/Pubs/10181.html (English), for more information about the documents you must provide to prove your immigration status.

Some ITINs must be renewed. If you did not use your ITIN when filing a federal tax return at least one time during 2021, 2022, or 2023 tax year, the ITIN will expire on December 31, 2024, and if you need to file a federal tax return for 2024, the ITIN must be renewed. You do not need to renew your ITIN if you do not need to file a federal tax return. To renew your ITIN, see Form W-7 and instructions at IRS.gov/FormW7. For more information, see IRS.gov/ITIN. ITINs issued before 2013 have expired, and if you need to file a tax return for 2024, they must be extended. If you previously filed an application for extension, and it was approved, you do not need to file an extension again if you did not use your ITIN in a federal tax return at least one time during 2021, 2022, or 2023 tax year.

The amount of your tax depends on your tax status. Your tax status is important for determining whether you can claim certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your filing status differ for foreign residents and non-resident aliens.

Foreigners-nonresidents who are married but not to US citizens or residents generally must use the 'Tax Table' or the 'Working Sheet for Calculating Tax for Married Filers Filing Separately' to determine the tax on income actually derived from professional or business activities in the US.

Foreign non-resident spouses generally cannot use the Tax Table or the Tax Calculation Worksheet for Married Filing Separate to file a tax return. However, you can file as a single taxpayer if you were separated from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a resident of Canada, Mexico or South Korea, married or a resident of a U.S. territory, married. See the instructions to Form 1040-NR to determine if you are eligible. The definition of a resident of a U.S. territory is given below in this section. Generally, a foreign non-resident cannot file a joint return. However, a foreign non-resident who is married to a U.S. citizen or resident may elect to be treated as a resident and file a joint return using Form 1040 or 1040-SR. Details about these options are in Chapter 1. If you decide not to file a joint return, complete Form 1040-NR and use the Tax Table or the Tax Calculation Worksheet for Married Filing Separate to file a separate return.

A foreign non-resident trust or estate using Form 1040-NR must use Schedule W in the instructions to Form 1040-NR to determine the tax on income actually derived from professional or business activities in the United States.

You must report each item of income that is taxable under the rules of the Code in chapters 1, 2, 3, and 4. For foreign residents, this includes income from sources both within and outside the United States. For foreign nonresidents, this includes income that is effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business (subject to the different tax rates) and income from sources in the United States that is not effectively connected (subject to a fixed tax rate of 30% or lower, or a lower tax rate under a treaty).

You can claim deductions to calculate your taxable income directly related to your U.S. business activities (English acronym ECTI). Generally, you cannot claim deductions related to income not related to your business activities in the U.S. An exception is certain itemized deductions, discussed below. You can claim deductions only to the extent they are related to income from your business activities in the U.S.

You can deduct all ordinary and necessary business expenses incurred in the United States to the extent they are connected to income actually derived from business. For more information about other business expenses, see the Business Expense Resources Guide (English).

If you paid interest in 2024 on an approved student loan, you may be able to deduct up to $2,500 of your interest payments. Generally, you can claim the deduction if you meet all the requirements. The deduction is taken in line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR. To figure the deduction, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English). For more information, see Publication 970 (English).

If you have income that is effectively derived from professional or business activities in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of the income from the appropriate professional or business activities, plus 20% of your income from your appropriate REIT and appropriate partnership, the shares of which are sold and purchased on an exchange (PTP). For further information, see line 13a in the instructions to Form 1040-NR (English). For further information on the deduction for income from appropriate business activities, see Form 8995 (English), Form 8995-A and their attachments, as well as the instructions for the forms and attachments.

If you were a qualifying employee of the education system in 2024, you can deduct as a correction to income up to $300 in unspent qualifying expenses that you paid or incurred during 2024 for certain courses of professional development, and for books and supplies (except non-sporting supplies for courses of health and fitness education or physical education), computer equipment (including appropriate software and services) and other additional equipment and materials that you use in your education. For more information, see the instructions to the tax form. Qualifying expenses include amounts paid or incurred after 2024 for personal protective equipment, disinfectant and other disposable supplies used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

If you made contributions to a traditional IRA for 2024, you can claim this deduction on your tax return. However, you must have taxable compensation, actually derived from professional or business activities in the U.S. Form 5498 must be sent to you by June 2, 2025; it will show all your traditional IRA contributions for 2024. If you were covered by a retirement plan (including a qualified pension plan, 401(k), annuity, SEP, SIMPLE, etc.), whether at work or self-employed, your IRA deduction may be reduced or eliminated. But you can still make traditional IRA contributions even if you can't deduct them. If you made non-deductible IRA contributions for 2024, you must report them on Form 8606. For more information, see Publication 590-A (English).

Relocation Expense Deduction is allowed only if you are a member of the United States Armed Forces on active duty and you are relocating due to a permanent change of station. For more information, see Publication 3 (English). If you meet these requirements, use Form 3903 to determine the amount of the deduction.

Do not include in income the value of relocation and storage services provided by the state due to a move in connection with a transfer to a new permanent place of service. Similarly, do not include in income amounts received as a relocation allowance, temporary living expenses, temporary living allowance or housing tax credit. For more information, see Publication 3 (English).

You must include in income all actually earned interest income that you receive or that is credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce it by any penalty that you must pay for early withdrawal of funds from a savings account. However, if the interest income is actually related to your professional or business activity in the United States during the year, you may deduct the penalty for early withdrawal of funds from a savings account, charged by a financial institution, in line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If a foreign person owns 100% of a non-legal entity located in the United States, such entity is considered a U.S. corporation separate from its owner (foreign person) for the purposes of Section 6038A, which applies to 25% of U.S. corporations owned by foreign owners. A non-legal entity located in the United States and owned by foreign owners must file Form 1120 and Form 5472 as an attachment to the tax return before the filing deadline (including any extension). If a non-legal entity located in the United States and owned by foreign owners has conducted professional, commercial or other reportable activities in the United States, it may have been subject to reporting requirements until 2017. For more information and the correlation with Form 5472, which must be filed by the non-legal entity located in the United States and owned by foreign owners, see the instructions to Form 5472. If you are unable to file your tax return on time, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing methods listed in the instructions for Form 4868. This way, for 2024, you can extend the filing deadline to October 15, 2025. If your filing deadline is June 16, 2025, you can extend the filing deadline to December 15, 2025. You must file a form to extend the filing deadline before the filing deadline. If you automatically extend the filing deadline for 6 months, the tax payment deadline is not extended. If you did not pay the tax by the original filing deadline, you will have a tax penalty. Also, there may be penalties. See Form 4868.

If your activity in the United States was limited, and you are certain that you did not receive any gross income in connection with professional or business activity in the United States during the year, you may file a tax return for non-taxable entities (Form 1040-NR) by the due date shown above. By filing this return, you protect your right to claim deductions and credits if it is later determined that some or all of your income is actually derived from professional or business activity in the United States. In the tax return for non-taxable entities, you are not required to report any income directly related to professional or business activity in the United States or any deductions, but you must justify the need to file this return. If you believe that some activity has resulted in income directly related to professional or business activity in the United States, you must file a tax return reporting such income and related deductions by the original due date. To protect your right to claim deductions or credits in connection with other activities, you must attach a statement to the tax return explaining that you want to protect your right to claim such deductions or credits if it is later determined that such activities resulted in income directly related to professional or business activity in the United States. If you believe that you have no tax liability in connection with activity in the United States under the tax treaty, you may take the same action. You must also complete Schedule L of Annex O (Form 1040-NR).

In your tax return, you must report all income from sources in the United States and from other sources. Information about filing a tax return for the U.S. Virgin Islands can be obtained from the IRS office for the Virgin Islands. If you are a bona fide resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands for the entire tax year and are temporarily working in the United States, you must pay income tax to the U.S. Virgin Islands and file a return at the following address: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802 . Chapter 8 describes the procedure for withholding taxes from U.S. wages for residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you are a resident of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) for the entire tax year, you must file a tax return and pay any required taxes under the laws of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands. In your tax return, you must report all income, including income from sources within the United States. You do not need to file a separate copy of the individual income tax return for the United States. Residents of Guam must file a Guam tax return at the following address. . Department of Revenue and Taxation Government of Guam P.O. Box 23607 Barrigada, GU 96921 . Residents of the Northern Mariana Islands must file a Northern Mariana Islands tax return at the following address. . Saipan Central Office Department of Revenue and Taxation P.O. Box 5234 CHRB Saipan, MP 96950 . If you are not a resident of Guam or the Northern Mariana Islands, see Publication 570 (English) for information about where to file your tax return.

If after filing your tax return you discover changes in your income, deductions or credits, you must file Form 1040-X. If instead of Form 1040-NR you should have filed Form 1040 or 1040-SR, or vice versa, you also must use Form 1040-X. If you are making changes to Form 1040-NR or filing an amended return, enter «Amended» («Amended») at the top of the document and attach to Form 1040-X the amended version of the tax return (Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-NR). Generally, to request a refund, the amended return must be filed within 3 years from the date you filed the original return or within 2 years from the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. The return filed before the due date is considered filed on time.
