Вы должны подать форму 8938, если общая стоимость этих активов превышает установленный порог («порог отчетности»). Порог отчетности зависит от того, проживаете ли вы на территории США, состоите ли в браке или подаете совместную налоговую декларацию по налогу на прибыль со своим супругом (своей супругой). Указанные иностранные финансовые активы включают любой финансовый счет, обслуживаемый иностранным финансовым учреждением. Кроме того, они включают удерживаемые в инвестиционных целях акции, ценные бумаги или любые другие доли в иностранной организации, а также любой финансовый инструмент или контракт с эмитентом или контрагентом, который не является субъектом США. Вам придется заплатить штраф в том случае, если вы не подали форму 8938, когда это требовалось, или если вы занизили сумму налога в результате любой операции, связанной со скрытыми иностранными финансовыми активами. Более подробную информацию о подаче формы 8938 можно найти в инструкциях к форме 8938 (Английский).

If you fail to file a tax return and pay the tax by the due date, you may be subject to a penalty. You will also be subject to a penalty if you significantly underestimate the tax amount, file an unreasonable tax return, or fail to provide your taxpayer identification number (TIN). If you provide false information in a tax return, you will be subject to a penalty for tax fraud.

If you fail to file your return by the due date (including the extension date), you will be subject to a penalty for failure to file. The penalty is based on the taxes not paid by the due date of your return (without regard to the extension date). Generally, the penalty is 5% per month or part of a month that your return is late, but not more than 25%.

Если статья в вашей декларации относится к налоговому убежищу, снижение суммы налога за адекватное раскрытие информации не производится. При этом производится снижение суммы налога за указание ссылки на авторитетный источник, но только в том случае, если вы обоснованно полагали, что примененный вами налоговый учет являлся правильным.

To properly disclose the relevant facts regarding the tax treatment of a particular item, use Form 8275, Disclosure Statement. You must also have a rationale for your treatment. In the case of a material overstatement of income, only those items disclosed in your return that meet the requirements of Revenue Procedure 2024-44, available at IRS.gov/irb/2023-51_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (English) (or a subsequent revision) are considered to be adequately disclosed in your return. Revenue Procedure 2024-44 does not take into account changes in the tax law that become effective in tax years beginning after December 31, 2024. If a line in the revenue procedure requires additional reporting, the taxpayer must file Form 8275 or Form 8275-R, Disclosure Statement, until regulations or other guidance are issued that take into account the change. A complete and accurate disclosure of the tax treatment in the UTP Schedule (Form 1120) for the tax year will be considered as filing Form 8275 or Form 8275-R for the tax position. However, filing Form 8275 or Form 8275-R will not be considered as filing the UTP Schedule (Form 1120). Use Form 8275-R to disclose items or tax positions that contradict the regulatory requirements.

You will not be subject to a penalty if you can justify the method of accounting for a particular item (provide a reasonable explanation). You must also demonstrate that you acted in good faith. This provision does not apply to transactions that lack economic substance.

You may be subject to a penalty for filing an incorrect refund or credit request. The penalty is 20% of the amount of the request that was denied. However, the penalty will not be imposed if you can show that you had a reasonable basis for filing the request. Any denied requests for transactions that do not have economic substance will be considered to have no reasonable basis. No part of the denied amount will be subject to a penalty if it is subject to a penalty for tax fraud or for providing false information to the tax authorities.

In the event that you file an unwarranted tax return or other unwarranted tax documents on you may be subject to a penalty of $5,000. An unwarranted tax return is a return that contains insufficient information to determine the correct amount of tax or contains information that clearly indicates that the stated amount of tax is incorrect. For more information on unwarranted tax returns, unwarranted tax documents, and the list of positions identified as unwarranted, see IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (English) (or subsequent revisions). You will be subject to a penalty for filing such a tax return or tax documents because of your unwarranted position or desire to delay or impede the enforcement of federal tax law. This includes changing or erasing preprinted text in the space intended for your signature. This penalty is in addition to any other penalties provided by law.
If there is a tax underpayment in your tax return due to tax fraud, a penalty of 75% of the amount of the underpayment due to tax fraud will be added to the amount of your tax.

If you do not report your Social Security Number (SSN) or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) or SSN or ITIN of another person in the appropriate fields of the tax return, report, or other document, you will be subject to a penalty of $50 for each omission. You may also be subject to a penalty of $50 if you do not report your SSN or ITIN to another person when it is required on a tax return, report, or other document. For example, if you have a bank account on which interest is paid, you must report your SSN or ITIN to the bank. This number must be reported on Form 1099-INT or other report that the bank will send you. If you do not report your SSN or ITIN to the bank, you will be subject to a penalty of $50. (You may also be subject to an additional withholding of income tax.) You will not be subject to a penalty if you can prove that you did not report the number for a valid reason, not because of intentional disregard.

If the taxpayer did not submit a tax return due to tax fraud, then the penalty for each full or incomplete month of delay in filing a tax return is 15% of the amount of tax payable, but not more than 75%.

If you file a tax return more than 60 days after the due date of the tax return or the due date of the tax return with extension, you are subject to a penalty of $510 or 100% of the amount of unpaid tax, whichever is less.

Если вы не подадите налоговую декларацию вовремя, то вам придется заплатить штраф. Однако вы можете избежать штрафа, если вы докажете, что вы не подали декларацию вовремя по обоснованной причине, а не из-за намеренного пренебрежения.

You will have to pay a penalty for late payment of tax equal to ½ of 1% (0.005) of the amount of unpaid taxes for each full or incomplete month after the due date of payment of the tax. This penalty does not apply during the automatic 6-month extension period for filing the tax return, if you have paid at least 90% of the actual amount of your tax liability by the due date of filing your tax return, and pay the balance when you file your return. The monthly penalty rate for late payment of tax is half of the standard rate of 1/4% (0.0025 instead of ½% (0.005)), if in this month there is a payment agreement. You must file your tax return by the due date (including extension periods) to be eligible for the reduced rate of penalty. In case of sending a notice of intention to charge tax, the rate increases by 1% at the beginning of the first month starting not less than 10 days after the day of sending the notice. If both a notice and a demand for immediate payment are sent, the rate increases to 1% from the beginning of the first month after the date of their sending. This penalty cannot exceed 25% of the amount of your unpaid tax. You will not have to pay a penalty if you can prove that you had a reasonable cause for late payment of tax.

If in one month both a penalty for failure to file a tax return and a penalty for failure to pay (see above) are applied, the penalty for failure to file in the amount of 5% (or 15%) is reduced by the amount of the penalty for failure to pay. However, if you file your tax return more than 60 days after the due date of filing the tax return or the due date of filing the tax return after an extension, you are assessed a penalty of $510 or 100% of the amount of the unpaid tax, whichever is less.

The penalty is equal to 20% of the amount of the tax underpayment. The penalty is 40% for any amount of underpayment relating to a non-disclosed transaction with no economic substance, or a non-disclosed transaction with a foreign financial asset. The penalty is not imposed on the amount of underpayment for which a tax fraud penalty is imposed (see below).

Negligence is a situation where a person fails to comply with tax law or fails to exercise reasonable care when preparing a tax return. Negligence also includes improper record keeping. You will not be penalized for negligence if you have a reasonable basis for your position.

You can avoid a penalty for failure to file a return or report if you properly disclose in your tax return the reason that has at least a reasonable basis. See the Disclosure of Information section below. This exception does not apply to items of the tax return related to tax haven. In addition, it will not apply if you do not maintain proper books of account or do not properly support an item of the tax return.

You may be subject to criminal prosecution for the following actions... 1. Tax evasion; 2. Willful failure to file a tax return, to provide required information, or to pay taxes due; 3. Tax fraud and false reporting; or 4. Filing and submitting a false tax return.

In this chapter, we discuss the procedure for paying income tax as you earn or receive income during the year. Generally, the federal income tax provides for payment from current income. There are two ways to pay taxes from current income. 1. Withholding. If you are an employee, your employer probably withholds income tax from your salary. Tax may also be withheld from some other income, such as pensions, bonuses, commissions, and gambling winnings. The withheld amount is remitted to the US Department of the Treasury on your behalf. 2. Estimated tax. If you do not pay taxes by withholding or do not pay enough taxes by that method, you will have to pay estimated tax. People who are self-employed usually pay taxes in this way. You will also have to pay estimated tax if you receive such income as dividends, interest, rental income, and capital gains, as well as royalties. Estimated tax is used to pay not only income tax, but also tax on professional income and the minimum alternative tax.

This is because such individuals pay income tax on the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid withholding on income earned in the United States, bona fide residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands should write a letter in duplicate to their employers stating that they are bona fide residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands and intend to pay tax on all income earned in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive pension payments in the United States, they are generally taxed at a 30% rate (or lower rate under a treaty). However, you may withhold tax at the progressive rate on that part of your pension that you began receiving after 1986 for services performed in the United States. To do this, you must complete Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and send it to the tax agent or payer before the income is paid to you or credited to your account.

Tips you receive during the year for services rendered in the United States are subject to income tax. You must include them in your taxable income. In addition, tips received while working for one employer and totaling $20 or more in any month are subject to progressive withholding.

If you and the person for whom you provide services do not fall under the definitions of "employee" and "employer", respectively, your cash compensation is subject to withholding at a rate of 30% (or a lower rate under the terms of the agreement). Social Security benefits are not subject to withholding at a 30% rate for a lawful permanent resident (green card holder). For U.S. income tax purposes, green card holders remain foreign residents until their status as a lawful permanent resident is terminated in accordance with immigration law or in an administrative or judicial proceeding. See the Green Card Test in Chapter 1. If you are a green card holder, and a tax was withheld from your Social Security benefits because your address was foreign, the IRS will refund the tax withheld. To get a refund, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. To determine if you are eligible for a refund, send your return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301. In addition, you must attach the following documents to your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. A copy of your SSA-1042S Statement of Social Security Benefits. A copy of your green card. A signed statement that includes the following: The Social Security Administration (SSA) mistakenly withheld income tax on Social Security benefits because I am a lawful permanent resident of the United States, and my green card has not been revoked. Its action has not been terminated in an administrative or judicial proceeding. I am filing a U.S. income tax return as a foreign resident and reporting all my income regardless of where it is earned. I have not applied for benefits in the tax year as a resident of a country other than the United States under a tax treaty.

Other types of income subject to the 30% (or lower) withholding rate generally include fixed or determinable income, such as interest (other than portfolio interest), dividends, pensions and annuities, and income from certain sales and exchanges, as described in Chapter 4. Other types of income also include 85% of Social Security payments to a nonresident alien.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. partnership or a foreign partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the partnership's directly related taxable income (DCTI). The partnership in which you are a partner may reduce the withholding tax rate on your share of the DCTI by offering certain partner level deductions. Generally, you will need to file Form 8804-C to do this. See the instructions to Form 8804 (English) for more information. Generally, the withholding tax rate on your share of the DCTI is the highest rate under Section 1, which is 37%. However, the partnership may withhold tax at the highest rate applicable to a particular type of income that you own if you provide the partnership with appropriate documentation. Long-term capital gains from the sale of capital assets is one example of a particular type of income to which the highest rate applies. Request a refund of the tax withheld as a credit by filing Form 1040-NR for 2024. The partnership will provide you with a Form 1042-S reporting the amount of tax withheld.

If you are employed in the United States, you must usually pay Social Security and Medicare taxes. By paying these taxes, you contribute to your Social Security benefits. Benefits include retirement payments, survivor benefits, and disability benefits, as well as Medicare insurance for people who meet certain requirements. In most cases, the first $168,600 of your taxable earnings received in 2024 for services performed in the United States are subject to Social Security tax. All taxable earnings are subject to Medicare tax. Your employer will withhold these taxes from each of your paychecks. Your employer is required to withhold these taxes even if you do not expect to receive Social Security or Medicare benefits. You can claim a refund of excess Social Security tax in your income tax return if you have multiple employers and the amount withheld from your total earnings for 2024 exceeds $10,453.20. If one of your employers withheld more than $10,453.20, you cannot claim a refund for that amount. Ask your employer to refund the excess tax. If your employer does not refund the excess tax, you can file a claim for refund using Form 843. Generally, Social Security and Medicare taxes in the United States are applied to earnings for services performed as an employee in the United States, regardless of the employee's or employer's citizenship or residence. In limited situations, these taxes may be applied to earnings for services performed outside the United States. Your employer should tell you if your earnings are subject to Social Security and Medicare taxes.

As a non-immigrant alien temporarily in the United States under the provisions of subsections (F), (J), (M), or (Q) of section 101(a)(15) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, your services generally are not covered by Social Security, if they are performed for the purpose for which you were admitted. This means that no Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from your earnings for these services. These types of services are very limited and generally include only work on the university campus, practical training, and work due to difficult economic conditions. Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from your earnings for these services if you are considered a resident alien, as explained in Chapter 1, even if your non-immigrant status («F», «J», «M», or «Q») remains the same.

If you are a non-resident alien student temporarily admitted to the United States, you are generally not allowed to work for pay or engage in business while in the United States. In some cases, a student admitted to the United States on F-1, M-1, or J-1 visas is permitted to work. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not withheld from the wages earned from employment if the student is not considered a resident alien. Any student who regularly attends classes may be exempt from Social Security and Medicare taxes on services performed for the institution. The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) permits on-campus employment for F-1 students if a U.S. citizen is not available to perform the work. On-campus employment means work performed on the campus of the educational institution. On-campus employment includes work performed off campus at a location that is related to the educational institution. Employment in the campus on a scholarship, grant, or assistantship basis is considered part of the student's academic program and is permitted by USCIS. Social Security and Medicare taxes are not withheld from the wages earned from such employment if the student is not considered a resident alien. If the services performed by a non-resident alien student are not considered to be performed for the purpose for which the student was admitted to the United States, Social Security and Medicare taxes will be withheld from the payment for these services, unless the payment is exempt from taxes under the Internal Revenue Code.

The United States has entered into social security agreements, commonly called ‘totalization agreements’ with foreign countries to coordinate social security coverage and taxation of workers employed partially or wholly in one of the countries. Under these agreements, double coverage and double contributions (taxes) for the same work are eliminated. Agreements usually provide that taxes in the social security fund (including self-employment tax) are paid only to one country. A list of the international social security tax agreements can be found on the SSA.gov/international/status.html (English). As agreements with other countries enter into force, they will be posted on this site. More information about international social security tax agreements can be found on the SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html (English).

As a rule, under these agreements, you pay social security taxes only in the country where you work. However, if you are temporarily assigned to work for the same employer in the U.S., and your salary is generally subject to social security taxes in both countries, most agreements provide that you are covered only by the social security system of the country from which you are assigned. To confirm that your salary is subject to taxes only in the foreign social security fund and is exempt from taxes in the U.S. social security fund (including the Medicare tax) under the agreement, you or your employer must request a coverage verification from the appropriate foreign tax authority. Usually this is the same authority to which you or your employer pay foreign social security taxes. The foreign authority can tell you what information is needed to issue a coverage verification. Your employer should keep a copy of the verification because it may be needed to prove that you are exempt from paying U.S. social security taxes. Only salary earned on or after the date the agreement goes into effect may be exempt from U.S. social security taxes.

This publication clarifies the procedure for taxation in the event of accidents, thefts, and losses on deposits. In the event of an accident, the property of a physical person suffers a loss as a result of such natural disasters as a hurricane, fire, car accident, and so on. In the event of theft, a third party illegally appropriates the property of a physical person. In the event of a loss on a deposit, the financial institution in which the deposit of a physical person is located becomes insolvent or declares bankruptcy. This publication addresses the following issues. Definition of an accident, theft, and loss on a deposit. Methods for determining the profit or loss of a physical person. How to use insurance and other forms of compensation for losses. Limitations on deductions. When and how to report an accident or theft. Special rules regarding losses in a disaster area.

All three types of loss relate to federally declared disasters, but the requirements for each are different. A federally declared disaster serves as the basis for the President of the United States to provide federal assistance under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes (a) a major disaster declaration or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

Federal accident loss is a loss of a person's personal property due to an accident or theft, which is related to a federal disaster declared in the state where the accident or theft occurred. The event that causes the accident loss must occur in a state where a federal disaster has been declared. If you have suffered a federal accident loss, you may claim a deduction. If you have suffered a loss of personal property due to an accident or theft that is not related to a federal disaster declared in the state where the accident or theft occurred, then the loss is not a federal accident loss, so you may not claim a deduction, except in special cases. Losses from thefts that occur during a transaction entered into for profit may still be claimed as a deduction. Note Caution in the section below entitled 'Deduction-eligible loss'.

You cannot claim any other deductions, including a loss from ordinary business operations on a deposit in an insolvent financial institution or in a financial institution that has declared bankruptcy.

You can deduct as a loss from business losses any loss on deposits in a financial institution that you can objectively calculate as a loss from the institution's insolvency or bankruptcy. Generally, you claim this deduction on the tax return you file for the year in which you suffered the loss. The deduction applies to all losses on deposits in the institution for that year. In the event of losses incurred due to an accident, you must submit the following documentary evidence. Proof that you are the owner of the property or the tenant of the property of another person and have fulfilled the terms of the rental agreement in the event of damage to the leased property. The type of accident (car accident, fire, extreme weather conditions, etc.) and the date of the accident. Proof that the losses were incurred directly as a result of the accident. The existence of a lawsuit for compensation, in accordance with which you can expect to receive a compensation amount.
To confirm your right to deduct taxes, you must submit the required reports. If you do not have such documents, you can submit other evidence.

If your property is insured, you should file a claim with your insurance company promptly to recover the loss. If you do not file such a claim, you will not be able to deduct the entire amount of the unrecovered loss as a casualty loss or theft loss. Only that portion of the loss that is not covered by your policy may be deducted. The portion of the loss that is usually not covered by insurance (for example, the amount for which you are liable, rather than the insurance) does not qualify under this rule.
The most common form of compensation is insurance payment for stolen or damaged property. Other forms of compensation are discussed further. Also see instructions to Form 4684.

If you receive money from your employer's disaster relief fund and you use that money to restore or replace property that you lost due to a disaster for which you are claiming a loss deduction, you must include the amount of the payment in your loss deduction calculation. Only include the amount that you used to replace the damaged or destroyed property.

If you receive non-taxable monetary gifts as a disaster victim, and there are no restrictions on how you can use the money, you won't reduce your disaster losses by the non-taxable monetary gifts. This applies even if you use the money to pay for repairs to property damaged by the disaster.

You do not reduce your losses from accidents by insurance payments you receive to cover living expenses in any of the following situations. You lose the opportunity to use your home because of an accident. The authorities have closed access to your main residence because of an accident or threat of its occurrence.

You include the taxable portion of the insurance payout in your income for the year in which you resume using your principal place of residence, or, if the insurance payout is received later, for the year in which you receive the taxable portion of the insurance payout.

You can claim a loss deduction for inventory loss due to an accident or theft, including inventory for sale, in two ways. The first way: claim a loss deduction for an increase in the cost of goods sold in the inventory report at the beginning and end of the tax period. You do not need to report these losses again as accident or theft losses. If you calculate the losses for an increase in the cost of goods sold, you must include the amount of any insurance or other compensation you received in gross income. The second way: claim a loss deduction separately. In this case, do not include the cost of the damaged property in the cost of goods sold and make an adjustment downward in the inventory report at the beginning of the tax period or in the sales report. Reduce the amount of the loss by the amount of the compensation received. Do not include the compensation in gross income. If you do not receive compensation for the loss by the end of the year, you cannot claim the loss to the extent you have a reasonable prospect of receiving it.

Repairs to damaged property are not included in the amount of loss from an accident. The cost of cleaning property after an accident is also not included in the amount of loss from an accident. For calculating the value of a car, you can use the guides published by the car manufacturers, in which the manufacturer and model of the car are indicated. Residential real estate for personal use is, as a rule, real estate, including its improvements, owned by a natural person who has suffered a loss from an accident, and including at least one object of residential real estate. This definition does not include personal housing, if any part of it is used for rental or contains a home office used for trade, business purposes or transactions for profit. For more information, see IRS Procedure 2018-08. IRS Procedure 2018-08 offers the following safe harbor methods for residential real estate for personal use. Repair value. Minimum amount. Insurance. Contractor's safe harbor. Damage assessment for a disaster loan.

If you suffered a loss in a disaster area and the loss was caused by a federal disaster, you may use the disaster area method or the disaster credit valuation method. Under the contractor's safe harbor method, you may use the amount stated in a contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the decrease in FMV of your personal residential real estate that was damaged by the disaster. This method is not applicable if you do not have a binding contract signed by you and the contractor that specifies the detailed costs of restoring your personal residential real estate to its condition immediately before the disaster.

Personal property is typically items of tangible personal property owned by an individual who is the victim of an accident or theft, if they are not used in trade or business. Personal property does not include items that retain or increase in value over time, as well as certain other types of property. For more information, see Tax Procedure 2018-08. The safe harbor methods for personal property are the minimum amount method and the safe harbor method for replacing property damaged by a disaster (for federally declared disasters).

The cost of protecting your property from an accident or theft is not part of the loss from an accident or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or to repair your home after a storm is not part of your losses. If the property is commercial, these expenses are deducted as business expenses. If you constantly improve your property to protect it from an accident or theft, add the cost of these improvements to your main property. An example is the cost of a dam built to prevent flooding.

If property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for commercial or income-producing purposes, the loss from accidents or theft should be calculated separately for the part used for personal purposes and for the part used for commercial purposes or income-producing purposes. EIC, or Earned Income Credit, is a tax credit for working people whose earned income is less than $63,398. It usually reduces your tax liability. EIC may allow you to get a refund.

To qualify for EIC, you (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) must have a valid SSN issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) by the filing deadline for your 2023 return (including extensions). If instead of a Social Security Number you (or your spouse in the case of a joint tax return) use an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN), you will not be able to get an EIC. If you are a nonresident alien temporarily present in the United States, you cannot receive EIC if you do not file a joint return. If your income from investment activity is $11,000 or less, you may be eligible for EIC. If your income from investment activity is more than $11,000, you are not eligible for EIC. To calculate your income from investment activity, use Worksheet 1 in this chapter.

This tax credit is called an earned income tax credit because you must work and earn income to receive it. If you are married or married and file a joint tax return, you can meet this rule if, at least, one spouse works and earns income. If you are an employee, your earned income includes all taxable income that your employer pays to you. Rule 15 contains information that you can use to calculate your earned income. If you are self-employed or a wage earner, you can calculate your earned income in the Work Sheet B EIC in the instructions for Form 1040 and 1040-SR.

Earned income includes the following types of income. 1. Wages, salary, tips, and other compensation for services rendered by an employee, subject to tax. Compensation for services rendered by an employee is earned income only if it is subject to tax. Compensation for services rendered by an employee that is not subject to tax, such as allowances for dependents and allowances for adoption of a child, is not earned income. However, there is an exception for non-taxable cash allowances for participation in combat: they can be included in earned income, as explained further in this chapter. 2. Net profit from the business of a self-employed person. 3. Gross income received by a salaried employee.
Wage, salary, and tips report, which you receive for the work you have done, is presented in line 1 of Form W-2. You must report the data amounts in line 1 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

Regardless of whether you have a Form 4361, the compensation you receive for performing the duties of a minister as an employee is considered earned income. This compensation includes piecework wages, hourly wages, tips, and other compensation for an employee's work that is subject to income tax. If you have a Form 4361, housing allowance that is not taxable or rent-free housing that is not taxable is not considered earned income. Also, compensation you received for performing the duties of a minister as an independent contractor is not considered earned income.

Regardless of whether you have a completed Form 4029, any wage income, including tips and other compensation for services performed by an employee, is taxable income. However, income you received as a self-employed person is not considered wage income. Also, when calculating the amount of each income, do not subtract expenses listed in Schedule C or F from the wage income listed in lines 1 through 1h of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

If you retired on disability, the taxable disability pension you receive under your employer's disability pension plan is considered earned income until you reach your minimum retirement age. Your minimum retirement age is usually the earliest age at which you can start receiving a disability pension or annual disability allowance. You must report the taxable disability pension in line 1h of Form 1040 or 1040-SR before you reach your minimum retirement age. After the date that is one day after you reach your minimum retirement age, the disability pension payments are taxed as a pension and are not considered earned income. You must report the taxable pension payments in lines 5a and 5b of Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

The payments you receive under a disability insurance program in which you have paid premiums are not earned income. In this case, it is not dependent on whether you have reached the minimum retirement age. If the program is administered by your employer, the amount may be reported in box 12 of your Form W-2 under code J.

Examples of non-earned income payments: interest and dividends, pension and annual allowance, social security and pension payments to railway employees (including disability allowance), alimony and child support, social benefits, compensation payments to employees, unemployment insurance (unemployment compensation), guardianship payments, veteran's benefits, including rehabilitation payments from the US Department of Veterans Affairs. Do not include any of the listed income in earned income.

If you are married but have the right to file a separate return or as the principal earner, under special rules for married taxpayers living apart (see Rule 3), and reside in a state with community property laws, no part of the earnings of your spouse, which are considered, under such laws, to be your property, is included in your earned income for the purpose of computing your EIC. For the purpose of computing your EIC, such earnings are not earned income. However, you must include such earnings in your gross income in your tax return. Your child is permanently and totally disabled if both of the following conditions are met. 1. He or she is unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of a physical or mental impairment. 2. A physician determines that such an impairment is expected to last for at least one year or is expected to result in death.

Substantial paid employment means the performance of substantial duties for a reasonable period of time in return for a salary or wage or in return for work which is normally done for reward or profit. Full-time (or part-time, as determined by the employer) employment in a competitive work environment, at least at the minimum wage, indicates that the child is capable of substantial paid employment. Substantial paid employment does not include work in connection with self-care or home maintenance. It does not include unpaid work in connection with hobbies, therapy or training in rehabilitation facilities, attending school, clubs, social programs, and the like. However, engaging in such work may indicate that the child is capable of substantial paid employment. The fact that the child has not worked for some time does not, in itself, indicate that the child is incapable of substantial paid employment. Examples of substantial paid employment are found in Publication No. 524.

If you have more than one child who meets the requirements and only one has a valid SSN, you can use only that child to get a higher EIC amount. For details about SSN, see Rule 2. If your child's Social Security card has “Not valid for employment” printed on it and your child's immigration status has changed and now he/she is a citizen or permanent resident of the U.S., ask SSA to issue you a Social Security card without that stamp. If you have a child who meets the requirements for EIC but that child does not have a valid SSN, you may be eligible to claim EIC without children.

If you and someone else have the same child who meets the criteria, but that other person cannot claim EIC because he or she is not entitled to it, or his or her earned income or AGI is too high, you may consider the child as meeting the criteria. See Examples 6 and 7. But you cannot consider the child as meeting the criteria if the other person claims the child for any of the four tax benefits listed earlier in this chapter.

For more information about your child's eligibility, see Rule 8. If you are a child who meets the requirements for another taxpayer, you cannot claim EIC. This is true even if the person for whom you are a child who meets the requirements does not claim EIC or does not meet all the rules for receiving EIC. Write «No» («No») in the dotted line next to line 27a (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

You must be between 25 and 65 years old at the end of 2023. If you are married and file a joint return, either you or your spouse must be between 25 and 65 years old at the end of 2023. Either spouse can meet the age requirement. You meet the age requirement if you were born after December 31, 1958 and before January 2, 1999. If you are married and file a joint return, you meet the age requirement if you or your spouse were born after December 31, 1958 and before January 2, 1999. If neither you nor your spouse meet the age requirement, you cannot claim the EIC. Write “No” in the dotted line next to line 27 (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

If you don't file a joint tax return, you meet this rule if you don't check the box next to your name that says "Someone can claim you as a dependent." If you file a joint tax return, you meet this rule if you don't check the box next to your name that says "Someone can claim you as a dependent" or the box next to your spouse's name that says "Someone can claim your spouse as a dependent." If you don't know if someone else can claim you as a dependent, see Publication 501, which explains the rules for claiming a dependent. If someone else can claim you as a dependent on their return but doesn't, you still can't claim the credit unless that person is required to file a return and doesn't or files a return only to get a refund of withheld income tax or paid estimated tax.

Generally, another person cannot claim you as a dependent if you are married and file a joint tax return. However, if you and your spouse file a joint tax return only to get a refund of income tax withheld from your wages or paid by payroll deduction, another person can claim you as a dependent. However, if you file an EIC on a joint tax return, another person cannot claim you or your spouse as a dependent.

See Rule 8 for more information on child's eligibility. If you are a qualifying child of another taxpayer, you cannot claim EIC. This restriction applies even if the person for whom you are a qualifying child does not file for EIC or does not meet all the rules for receiving EIC. Enter 'No' ('No') on the dotted line next to line 27a (Form 1040 or 1040-SR).

As a rule, you cannot be a qualifying child of another taxpayer if you are married and file a joint tax return. However, if you and your spouse file a joint tax return only to get a refund of income tax withheld from your wages or to pay estimated tax, you may be a qualifying child of another taxpayer. However, if you claim the EIC on a joint tax return, neither you nor your spouse can be a qualifying child of another taxpayer.

As a rule, earned income is wage earnings, wages, tips, and other compensation for an employee's services, subject to withholding tax, and net profit from the activities of a self-employed person. Wages for an employee are earned income only if they are taxable. Wages for an employee that are not taxable, such as allowances for dependents and adoption allowances, are not earned income. However, there is an exception for non-taxable cash allowances for participation in combat: they can be included in earned income. For more information on earned income, see Rule 7 in Chapter 1.

Before completing the schedule, make sure to read the section on “Clergy” or “Church Employees” if it applies to you.

Sharon Jamie is 63 years old and retired. During the year, she received Social Security payments of $7,000 and income from part-time employment of $17,000. In addition, she received taxable pensions of $7,400. Sharon had no other income. Her adjusted gross income, as shown in line 11 of Form 1040, was $24,400 ($17,000 + $7,400). Sharon is not married, and she lived alone in the U.S. for the entire year. She cannot be claimed as a dependent on the tax return of any other person. She has no investment income and no child who qualifies as a dependent. Sharon should follow the instructions in the Form 1040 instructions. On Step 1, she discovers that because her AGI ($24,400) is not less than the threshold amount of $24,210, she cannot claim EIC. She completes the rest of the Form 1040 and files it with the IRS.

Cynthia and Jerry Gray have two children: Kirk, 10 years old, and Suzanne, 8 years old. The children lived with Cynthia and Jerry throughout 2023. Cynthia earned $15,000 in wages, and Jerry earned $18,030 in wages. The Gray family received $525 in interest on their savings account. They had no other income in 2023. Cynthia and Jerry have a Form 1040 for 2023 and the instructions to it. They want to know if they are eligible for EIC, and therefore follow the step-by-step instructions for line 27.

The amount shown by Cynthia and Jerry on line 11 of Form 1040 is $23,555. Both have had SSN's for many years. They are married and intend to file a joint return. Neither Cynthia nor Jerry are foreign nationals. Therefore, the answers they give to the questions in Step 1 allow them to proceed to Step 2.
The only investment income of the Gray family is $525 in interest. This amount does not exceed $11,000, so they answer "No" to the second question in Step 2 and proceed to Step 3.
Cynthia and Jerry calculated that their income is $33,030 — the sum of their total earnings. This is less than $59,478, so they go to Step 6 to figure out the credit they're eligible for.
Cynthia and Jerry want to calculate their own EIC, so they fill out the EIC worksheet in the instructions to Form 1040 (see below).

Cynthia and Jerry fill out their work sheet as follows. 1. Cynthia and Jerry enter their total earned income (33,030 USD) in line 1. 2. To determine their deduction, they refer to the EIC table. They find their income of 33,030 in the range of 33,000 USD to 33,050 USD. Since their children have valid SSN, they go down the line to the column for two children under the category «Married filing jointly» and find the amount of 5,571 USD. They enter 5,571 USD in line 2. 3. They enter their AGI (33,555 USD) in line 3 and see that it is different from the amount in line 1. 4. They find 33,555 USD in the EIC table and enter the amount of 5,455 USD in line 5. 5. They enter 5,455 USD in line 6. This is the smaller of the amount in line 2 (5,571 USD) and the amount in line 5 (5,455 USD). 6. The Gray family enters 5,455 USD in line 27 of Form 1040. They then fill out the EIC table (see below) and attach it to their return. They keep the EIC work sheet for their records.

Due to their special relationship with the taxpayer, the following persons may represent the named taxpayers before the IRS, provided they present satisfactory identification and, except in the case of a natural person described in paragraph (1) below, evidence of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. Natural person. A natural person may represent himself before the IRS and need not file a written statement of qualification and authority. 2. Family member. A person may represent his or her immediate relatives. Immediate family includes spouse, child, parent, brother or sister of the person. 3. Corporate officer. An officer of a corporation (including a parent, subsidiary or other affiliated corporation), association or organized group may represent the corporation, association or organized group. An officer of a state or local government agency or other entity having authority may represent the state or local government agency or other entity having authority before the IRS. 4. Partner. A general partner may represent a partnership before the IRS. 5. Employee. A full-time state employee may represent his or her employer. A definition of employer includes, but is not limited to, a natural person, partnership, corporation (including a parent, subsidiary or other affiliated corporation), association, trust, foreign management, guardianship, estate, organized group, state or local government agency or other entity having authority. 6. Fiduciary. A fiduciary (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, receiver or guardian) acts as a taxpayer and acts as a taxpayer, not as a representative. See Fiduciary in the When a Power of Attorney Is Not Required section further below.
Any registered agent with an active status who is not currently suspended or disqualified from representing before the IRS may represent before the IRS.

Generally, individuals who do not meet the participation criteria or have lost their privilege as a result of certain actions cannot represent themselves before the IRS. If a natural person loses the right to represent, the IRS does not recognize a power of attorney in which the individual is listed as the representative.

The IRS will send a notice to registered individuals and individuals with a confirmation of completion of the Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) who do not meet the requirements for an extension. The notice will explain the reason for the rejection and provide an opportunity to submit information for reconsideration in a timely manner.

A registered person must submit an application for extension within 3 years, and meet all requirements for extension after being transferred to an inactive status. Otherwise, at the end of the next extension cycle, it will be removed from the list, and the registration status will be canceled.

Registered individuals who request a transition to inactive status will not be eligible to represent in IRS. They must continue to comply with all extension requirements. They can be restored to active registration status by filing an extension and providing evidence that they have completed the required hours of continuing professional education for the certification cycle.

All persons appearing before the IRS are subject to disciplinary action and may be subject to reprimand, suspension, disbarment, or monetary penalty for violation of any provision of the Circular 230. This includes participation in activities demonstrating incompetence or improper conduct. For more information, see the “Incompetence and Improper Conduct” section in the “What are the rules of representation” section further below. Practitioners who are suspended or disbarred during a disciplinary proceeding may not represent taxpayers before the IRS during the period of suspension/disbarment. A practicing attorney may apply for reinstatement to the Practice Management Division before the end of the suspension period or after five years of imprisonment. See What is representation before the IRS above. If a practicing attorney seeks reinstatement, he or she may not represent before the IRS until the Practice Management Division approves the reinstatement. The Practice Management Division may reinstate a practicing attorney: if the attorney’s future conduct is unlikely to be a violation of the rules, and if granting reinstatement would not be contrary to the public interest, subject to other conditions and for a reasonable period of time.

Individuals who fall under the scope of Circular 230 cannot sign any check (including directing or receiving payment in any manner, electronic or otherwise, to a account owned or controlled by the specialist, or any firm or other entity with which the specialist is associated), issued by the client as a federal tax liability.

Individuals who fall under the scope of Circular 230 may be denied the right to practice law or be disbarred by the IRS, and may be disciplined for incompetence or misconduct. Monetary penalties may also be imposed, in addition to any other discipline, on individuals and their firms. Examples of misconduct are listed in Section 10.51(a) of Circular 230. Examples include: Being convicted of any criminal offense under the tax laws or of any offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Knowingly providing false or misleading information in connection with federal tax matters or engaging in such activity. Extorting work by means of prohibited means, as discussed in Section 10.30 of Circular 230. Willfully failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, and engaging in such activities. Misappropriating or failing to properly and timely remit funds received from clients for payment of taxes or other obligations due the United States. Attempting to influence directly or indirectly the official action of IRS employees by means of threats, false accusations, pressure or coercion, or by offering gifts, services or any special inducements. Being disbarred or suspended from practice as an attorney, certified public accountant, public accountant or actuary by the District of Columbia or any state of the United States, territory, commonwealth, any federal court, any federal agency, body or board. Using offensive language, making false accusations or statements, spreading or publishing malicious or libelous material, and engaging in any disrespectful behavior in the practice before the IRS. Giving false testimony knowingly, recklessly or through gross incompetence; or engaging in a scheme to provide incompetent opinions on matters arising under the federal tax laws.

Attorneys, licensed accountants and registered agents may perform the following actions: 1. Represent you before any IRS office or employee. 2. Sign an offer or waiver of restriction on assessment or collection of tax, as well as a waiver of notice of failure to satisfy a tax credit or refund claim. 3. Sign a consent to extend the statutory period of assessment or collection of tax. 4. Sign a final agreement.

When the form is signed by a representative, a power of attorney (or a copy) authorizing the representative to sign the form must be attached. For more information, see the instructions for Form 2848.

A power of attorney usually terminates if you become incapacitated or incompetent. However, a power of attorney may be extended in the event of your incapacity or incompetence, if you authorize it in line 5a «Other actions authorized» Form 2848, and if your long-term power of attorney, not IRS-related, meets all requirements for IRS acceptance. See Power of Attorney, Not IRS-Related further.

Submit a power of attorney if you want to authorize a physical person to receive your confidential tax information and represent you before the IRS, regardless of whether the representative performs any of the other actions mentioned above in What is a power of attorney? A power of attorney is most often required when you want to authorize another person to perform at least one of the following actions on your behalf. 1. Represent you at a meeting with the IRS. 2. Prepare and file a written response to an IRS request.

IRS will not accept your non-IRS power of attorney if it does not contain all the above information. You can sign and send a completed Form 2848 or a new non-IRS power of attorney that contains all the information. If you cannot sign an acceptable substitute document, your representative may improve (make acceptable to IRS) your non-IRS power of attorney by the procedure described below.

If the following conditions are met, a representative named in your non-IRS power of attorney may sign Form 2848 on your behalf. 1. The original power of attorney is non-IRS and provides power to handle federal tax matters (e.g., general power to do any act). 2. The representative attaches to Form 2848 a statement (signed under penalty of perjury) stating that the non-IRS power of attorney is valid under the law of the jurisdiction where it was executed.

The IRS has a centralized computer system of databases called the CAF system. This system contains information about the authority of the taxpayer's representative. Usually, when you file a power of attorney with the IRS, it is processed to be included in the CAF system. The entry of your power of attorney in the CAF system allows IRS employees who do not have a copy of your power of attorney to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the CAF. It also allows the IRS to automatically send copies of notices and other IRS messages to your representative if you indicate that your representative should receive these messages. You can enter your non-IRS power of attorney in the CAF system by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and filing it with the IRS. Your signature is not required, however, your representative by power of attorney must sign the Representative's Declaration (see Part II of Form 2848).

As a general rule, you can send Form 2848 by mail or fax directly to the IRS. To determine where you must file Form 2848, see Where to File in the instructions to Form 2848. If Form 2848 is for a specific use, send it by mail or fax to the office handling that matter. For more information about a specific use, see Line 4. Specific Use, Not Stated in CAF in the instructions to Form 2848.

IRS will accept a copy of the power of attorney provided by fax. If you decide to send the power of attorney by fax, make sure the IRS office that is handling your case is equipped to receive such mailings. Your representative may file Form 2848 electronically through the IRS website. For more information, your representative may call 1-800-829-1040. If you are completing Form 2848 to authorize electronic signatures, do not file Form 2848 with IRS. Instead, send it to your representative who will keep the document.

Please submit any update or change to an existing power of attorney in writing. A signature (or signature of the person(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Submit this by mailing an updated Form 2848 or power of attorney that is not IRS-specific to the IRS office(s) to which you previously mailed the original(s), including the service center where the return was or will be filed. A recognized representative may replace or delegate authority if you specifically authorize your representative to replace or delegate representation in the original power of attorney. To make a replacement or delegation of authority, the representative must file the following documents with the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney was filed: 1. A written notice of replacement or delegation, signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written statement by the representative, made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the replacement or delegation.

The new power of attorney for the same matter cancels the previously submitted power of attorney. However, the new power of attorney does not cancel the previous power of attorney if it specifically states that it does not cancel the previous power of attorney and the new power of attorney includes one of the following clauses. A copy of the previously revoked power of attorney, or A statement signed by the taxpayer, with the name and address of each representative authorized under the previously revoked power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a previously executed power of attorney and do not want to appoint a new representative, you must write “REVOKE (REVOKE)” at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with your current signature and date directly below that annotation. Then you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation annotation to the IRS using the Where to File table in the instructions for Form 2848 or, if the power of attorney is for a specific issue, — to the IRS office handling that issue. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney you want to revoke, you must send to the IRS a statement of revocation that lists the powers of attorney revoked, lists the issues and years/periods, and lists the name and address of each recognized representative whose powers were revoked. You must sign this statement and date it. If you completely revoke the powers of attorney, write “remove all years/periods (remove all years/periods)” instead of listing specific issues and years/periods.

If your representative wants to withdraw from representation, he or she must write “WITHDRAW (REVOCATION)” at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date directly under the annotation. In this case, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation annotation to IRS in the order described in Subsection Revocation, made by the taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney and he or she wants to revoke it, he or she must send to IRS a revocation statement which indicates the authority, the revoked power of attorney, lists the issues, years/periods, names, TIN and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date this statement. The power of attorney on file with the student will be registered in the CAF system for 130 days from the date received. If you allow the student to represent you after this period, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

For tax years of partnerships beginning after December 31, 2017, the Two-Party Budget Act of 2015, which eliminated the TEFRA audit and litigation procedures and the rules applicable to the election of large partnerships, and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, eliminated the role of “tax matter partner” and replaced it with “partnership representative.” In accordance with § 301.9100-22T of the Treasury Regulations, some partnerships may elect to apply the new regime to partner returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015 and before January 1, 2018.

Authorization is recognized after it is received by IRS, verified for the presence of all necessary information, and approved. However, until the authorization is registered in the Centralized Authorization File, IRS may not know about the authority of the person whom the taxpayer has chosen as his representative. Therefore, during the registration period, IRS may request the taxpayer or his representative to provide a copy of the authorization at every meeting with IRS.

If Form 2848 is incomplete, IRS will attempt to determine the missing information in a letter or telephone call to the taxpayer or his representative. For example, if the document is missing a signature or date, IRS will contact the taxpayer. If the information about the taxpayer's representative is missing but sufficient data is available to contact (e.g., address and/or phone number), IRS will attempt to contact the representative. Otherwise, the power of attorney will be deemed invalid until the missing information is received. The person(s) listed as the representative(s) will not be considered by IRS as having authority to act on behalf of the taxpayer until the form is fully completed and approved by IRS.

If the power of attorney is full and valid, IRS will start the procedure to approve the representative. In most cases, this procedure includes processing the document in the Centralized Authorization File. The entry of data in the Centralized Authorization File allows IRS to send copies of documents sent to the taxpayer by mail to the representative and to recognize the representative's authority in the extent to which the taxpayer has empowered him.

Specific powers of the representative are not processed in the Centralized Authorization File (see Preparing the form — Useful tips above). For example, a power of attorney signed for a single action or empowering the representative with specific powers is not processed in the Centralized Authorization File. Such documents remain among the files related to the matter. In such cases, the taxpayer must check the box in line 4 of Form 2848. In such cases, the representative must bring a copy of the power of attorney to each meeting with IRS.

The IRS uses the latest encryption technologies to allow taxpayers to make secure electronic payments. An electronic payment can be made online, by phone, or through the IRS2Go mobile app. Electronic payments are faster and easier than paying by check or money order. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to pay taxes using any of the following features. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your individual tax bill or estimated tax directly from your current or savings account for free. Debit or credit card: To pay online, by phone, or from a mobile device, you must choose an approved payment system. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Only available when filing your federal tax return using tax preparation software or a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System: Best for businesses. Registration is required. Check or Money Order: Mail your payment to the address shown on your notice or instructions. Cash: Pay your taxes with cash at any participating store.

The Taxpayer Assistance Centers are independent organizations from the IRS. Taxpayer Assistance Centers represent taxpayers with incomes below a certain level and who need to resolve problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax collection issues. In addition, a taxpayer can get information about their rights and responsibilities in different languages (especially for those who speak English as a second language). Services are provided free of charge or for a small fee. A list of centers can be found at: TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap (English) or in Publication IRS #4134, List of Taxpayer Assistance Centers (English).

Go to the IRS.gov/Account link to securely view your personal federal tax account information. This includes the amount of debt, online payment, and online payment agreement. Tax payment reports are available online. Review your payment history for the last 18 months. Go to the IRS.gov/SecureAccess link to complete the required identification process.

The fastest way to get a tax refund - direct deposit to your account and electronic filing. With direct deposit, your tax refund is safely deposited electronically directly to your bank account. 8 out of 10 taxpayers get their tax refund by direct deposit. IRS issues more than 90% of payments within 21 days.

In connection with changes in legislation, IRS may make payments of tax refunds for which applications were filed in relation to the tax credit for earned income (EIC) or additional tax credit for a child (ACTC), no earlier than mid-February 2018. This provision applies to the entire payment, not only to the part related to the above tax credits.

Go to the link IRS.gov/Tools to find the following tools. The Earned Income Tax Credit Assistant (IRS.gov/EIC) will help determine if you qualify for the Earned Income Tax Credit (EIC). The Employer Identification Number (EIN) Application (IRS.gov/EIN) will help you get an Employer Identification Number (EIN). The Tax Withholding Calculator from IRS (IRS.gov/W4App) will help you calculate the amount that should be withheld from your paycheck as federal income tax. The Home Buyer's Tax Credit Account Lookup Tool (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer) will help you find all the information about your payments and check the status of your account. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/SalesTax) will help you calculate the amount you can claim as a non-itemized deduction on Schedule A (Form 1040) if you don't claim state and local income tax deductions and don't have receipts for sales tax paid.
